 cilio, in the eneral Council of Lateran, 1515; the au-
 thority of w ich is acknowledged in the tenth rule of
 the Tridentine Index. In this decree the Pope corn-
 plains that some persons presume to print, and sell
 publickly, books containing errors in faith, and per-
 nicious doctrines, ac contra famam personarum, etiam
 dignitate fulgentium. He then states, that in conse-
 quence of such proceedings, various scandals have often
 arisen; and his conjectural, foreboding prophecy, maiora
 indies exoriri formidantur, was not in time without its
 due fulﬁlment. It is important also to observe, that
 -the Vicar of his Holiness, and the Master of the Sacred
 Palace, are appointed to examine, and grant a, license
 for_printin books in Rome; while in other places this
 was to be one by the Bishop, or his Deputy, and the
 Inquisitor of heretical pmity.‘ If any Printer"l should
 oﬁ’end, the books were to be burned _: he Wu toOOpay

 - Some notice should be taken‘of the Bull in Omna
 Domini, because of its int'nnate connexion with the In-
 dexes of prohibited books.

 _ In diﬁ'erent parts of his Bullsrium‘, Cherubin refers
 to the account he has givenq of this annual Anathema,‘
 Tom. III. . 183; in which place mention is made of
 all the Bu] 3 of this kind, ex quibus pro temporum con-
 ditione, Romanos Pontiﬁces aliquid immutasse cognos-

 It is unnecessary to pursue this subject farther : but
 before I proceed to other matters, I am glad to avail

 Literary Policy of the Church of Home,” cannot be dis-
 pensed with by any one, who is anxious to bemade ac-

 minted with facts, about which it is enough to say,
 are as im taut as they are generally unknown.

 ε An exception to this rule must be made, in the case of a hereﬁc
 efformet times, and especially if he was one of the ﬁrst magnitude.
 For instance, Raimundus Lullius, who bad long borne that character,

 edoctus a diabolo, me» having had his sentence conﬁrmed in {In

 Returnin at length to the place from which I have
 vwandered, ä ﬁnd these writers, Desiderius Erasmus
 Roterodamus, Nilus Thessalonicensis, Nicolaus Cle-
 mangis, Beatus Rhenanus, and Vldaricus Zasius, ranked
 in the Index. Romanus amongst those, quorum libri
 ’ ᾇ· ocripta omnia prohibentur ,· but in the Index of
 Sixtus V., and in that of Clement VIII., they are, at
 the imminent risk of Papal consistency, removed into -
 the second class, the censure of which is less severe.
 Again, these Popes prohibit Corranza’s Catechism,
 which was formally approved of by the deputed Con-
 gregation of the Counci of Trent, though the attestation ~
 was afterwards withdrawn0. ‘ ' ›

 Erasmus,

 ° Hist. du Cone. de Traute, T. 4ΙΙ. pp. 556-7. A Lond.~
 MDCCXXXVI. When Pos‘sevinus (Appar. Sac. Tom. I. p. 183.
 Venet. MDCIII.) says of this author, alicubi lapsus est in ipsa
 Conciliorum Summa, he is ungrateful for exertions made to defend
 his Church in the only feasible way. Carranza’s Epitome was
 printed, “for the more general spreading of the corrupted Councils.”
 (Comber’s Rom. Forg.‚ p. 116.) For example, when the Council of
 Laodicea, Can. xxxv., declares: Quod non oportet Christianos,
 relicta Dei Ecclesia, abire, & Angelos nominare, &c., (Bevet.
 Pandect. Tom. l. p. 468.) we here read Austria». The Canon
 was ﬁrst falsiﬁed either by Isidorus Mercator, or James Merlin, who
 published his Collection. (Tom. I. Concil. Colon. 1530., et Paris.

 MDCXIX. Mr. Mendham (p. 78.) had said of the expurgatory
 Index of1571, that it “could not even he possessed without epieco-
 pal permission." A writer in The Church of England Quarterly
 Review for April 1837, making the usual confusion about the two
 kinds of Indexes, and probably having this passage before him, asks,
 (p. 600.) “ will it be believed, that to this ecclesiastical tyranny was
 frequently snperadded the diﬂlculty of obtaining the very index
 which comprised the list of condemned books ? That, in some
 cases, it could not be obtained without episcopal permission? Yet
 such is* the historical fact." The reviewer of the Literary Policy
 would have done well in attending to what is stated, p. 4, of the pro·-
 hibitory Catalogue; that, “no attempt or wish is discoverable to pre-
 vent its most extensive publicity, at least in countries professing the
 papal faith." ’ ”

 xl i v Preface.

 In this Belgiclndex, the Divines of Douay make known
 a principle of their art of criticism, which is worthy of
 immortal memory. Under the letter B, “ Vt liber Bertra-
 mi Presb. de corp. & sang. Domini, tolerari emendatus
 queat,” their judgment is: Cum-in catholicis veteribus
 aliis plurimos feramus errores, δι extenuemus, excuse-
 mus, excogitato commento persaepe negemus, Stcommodn
 iis sensum aﬁ'mgamus, du opponatur in disputationibus,
 aut in condictionibus cü aduersariis: non videmus, cur
 non eandem aequitatem δι diligentem recognitionem me-
 reatur Bertramus ; ne heretici ogganniant nos ‘anti uita-
 tem pro ipsis facientem exurere δι prohibere : 'c.—-
 The, whole article is a magniﬁcent sample of Romish
 ﬁdelity. The Censors having done what they could in
 the way of exposition, are obliged to dispose of some
 very troublesome passages, by saying that they are in-
 terpolations : Non male aut inconsulte omittantur
 iyitur omnia hoec. . . . According to Cave, Ratramn
 lived in the year 840. Bellarminh says, that circa an.
 886, “ in controuersiam vocare coepit, an esset vere in
 Eucharistia illud ipsum corpus Domini, quod de Vir-
 gine natum erat.” His book has consequently been
 prohibited, from the time of Paul IV. Gretser’s maxim
 is of the utmost importance : Dum rohibetur Bertra-
 mus, nego' prohiberi Patrem: Nam eclesiae pater ille
 dicitur, qui Ecclesiam salutari doctrina alit & pascit,
 qui super familiam Domini constitutus, dat ei in tem-
 pore tritici mensuram. ,Iam ergo si pro salutiferae
 doctrinae pabulo, 8ι pro mensura tritici offerat ἃ adme-
 tiatur lolium 8ι zizania, & peruersorum dogmati) lappas
 8c tribulos; eatenus non pater est, sed vitricus; non
 doctor, sed seductore δι quod hinc sequiturgblcjguando

 Gabriel Putherbeus wrote a volume, De tollendis

 ezpunyfedis malis libris, Paris. 1549. 8vo., which

 have fortunatel been able to procure. Gretser speaks
 of him thus : “ aeteris copiosius 8c ex professo mate-

 ' riem hanc exsecutus est.” (De ivre &c. Praei), ad ﬁn.)

 Dr. James, p. 380, says, “ he hath discovered the fraud
 of their Bishops, Priests, and Monks, better than any
 man that I do know.” In pp. 23-4, he states, that the
 writers of infamous books are praised, and honoured,
 instead of being restrained ; that libri mali etiam cum
 priuilegio rodeunt; p. 85, episcopos habent traduc*
 tores ; and) p. 115, that they are found inter ornaméta
 ontiﬁcum ; at which there is the proper exclamation,

 arti' 1664.

 Bthhe rules of the Tridentine Index, there is a good
 deal of liberty allowed to Bishops, and general Inquisi—
 tors. A section in the tenth gives them power, when
 they think it expedient in the Kingdom, Province, or
 Diocese, to which they belong, to prohibit books, the
 use of which seems to be permitted ; and by the sixth
 they are authorized to favour the circulation of the
 amended works of Catholics, which had been probi-
 bited before correction : but as of course their privi- -
 leges were conﬁned within certain limits, and as it was
 here declared, that the sentence of excommunication
 was ipso facto incurred by any person, who should read
 or possess the writings of a forbidden author, nothing
 remained for the S niards,‘ whose favourites were
 often condemned at me, but to weaken the inﬂuence,
 and disregard the decrees of the Congregation of the
 Index. Of this Raynaud says very justly: in contemp-
 tionem Pontiﬁcim antoritatis, qua huiusmodi Censores
 constituti sunt male vertitur.‘

 The case of Joannes Baptista Poza will furnish us
 with perhaps the most memorable instance of the hos-
 tility that existed between the Spanish and Roman Cen-
 sors. His Elvoidarivm Deipara was published at
 Complutum in 1626, fol., and was reprinted at Lyons
 in 1627, Superiorum permissu, in 4; but it was pro-
 scribed at Rome, die 11. Ap.“ 1628. All the works of

 ° Troili de Ia morale det Pera. A Amat. MDCCXXVHI.

 f Free Inquiry, and Intr. Disc. Dub. MDCCXLIX.

 ’8 Dissert. de S. Script. interpret. sec. Pat. Comment. Land.
 MDCCXIV. Toplady says rather contemptuously : “ Some excel-
 lent things are, indeed, interspersed in their writings; bulthe golden
 grains are almost lost amidst an inﬁnity of rubbish.” (Meditations,
 p. 125. Dub. 188].) l am sorry to ﬁnd that Mr. M‘Ghee imagines,
 that references to Councils, and Fathers, only give rise to “absurd
 and hopeless ‘questions;" and that “in the use of these weapons,
 with which alone their Church can be defended, several of the Roman
 Catholic Priests, men of learning, and genius, and abiliiy, are per-
 fectly competent to meet any of the most able opponents, who could
 be arrayed in discussion against them.” (Truth and Error contrasted,-
 p. 279. Dub. 1830. Vide Address to R. C.‚ pp. xxix-xxx.) Mr.
 Finch declares it to be his purpose, “ to sink the Fathers ;" whose
 works “ present us with a chaotic confusion, which renders all the
 eﬂ‘orts of the controversialist, who is so ignorant or so papisticai as
 to appeal to them in support of his doctrines, perfectly nugatory."
 (Sketch of the Romish Controversy, Preface, pp. iv-v. Lond. 183l.)
 Mr. Maurice, with a ﬁrst-rate neoteric spirit, considers the Fathers
 as “little deserving our notice on points of doctrine," and thinks
 that “ they may he made to say any thing we please.” (The
 Popery of Oxford I p. 62. Lond. 1837.) These are the prevailing
 notions of modern times; and it Ought not to recommend them
 to us, to know, that Socinians make use of similar language.
 Smalcius says: Totius mundi (preter Apostoloa) authoritas in
 religione ’nulla est. (Refut. 2. lib. Smigleéii, de error. non. Arias).
 Vide Barlow’s Directions, p. 21.) It is easy to understand why
 Gibbon constantly sneers at the early Christian writers; and also
 what reason the author of the Second Travel: of an Irish Gala
 tleman had, for expressing himself, “ with little respect for the judg-
 ment, and knowledge of those pretended varicles oflridilion, the
 Fathers." (Vol. 1. p. 152. Dub. 1833.) The best antidote against
 such opinions, as farn they relate to Popery, may be found in the
 challenge of the illustrious Jewel,‘ who selects twenty-seven dis—
 puted points, and declares; that “ if any man aliue were able to
 prone any of these .articles, by any one cleere or plalne clause or
 sentence either of the Scriptures, or of the old Doctours, or stony

 ’ῦπαρ-μω.

 Preface. [xxv

 revere antiquity. The Church of Rome hasnot been
 wanting in the pretension: but, instead of revering
 anti uity, she has idolized herself. The Church of
 England, alone, has adopted a middle course; moving
 in the same delightful path, and treading in the same
 hallowed footsteps, with Vincentius, and the Catholic
 Bishops, and the ancient Fathers : proceeding as far as
 the ' proceeded, and stopping where they stopped.”
 “ Ῑὲο well-taught member of that Church needs hesi-
 tate or tremble. His path is plain. It is not, merely,
 his own judgment; it Is not, by any means, the dictate;
 rial mandate of an ecclesiastical director, which is to
 silence his scruples, and dissolve his doubts. His
 resort is, that concurrent, universal, and undeviating
 tense of pious antiquity,i which he has been instructed,
 and should be encouraged, to embrace, to follow, and
 revere.”

 Per fidem, sicut scriptum est.”¹¹-Ex eiusdem Cyrilll

 antur ex margins illa verb. Ocatio ad libertatem
 per ﬁdem in Christum facts. Qua: in textu etiam, g(
 indice litera. V. continentur.’⁷ ”
 The Commentary u on Genesis, attributed to Euche-
 rius, is puriﬁed by t e same Index (fol. 114.) in two
 laces. For Anima peccatrix esse desmit, it re uires to
 ge read, anima peccatrix esse non desinit; whitil] emen- '
 dation seems quite necessary : so that Dr. James need
 “ not have been indignant at this “ o en Contradiction.”
 Several lines of the text are anni ilated in the other
 instance; but I shall not cite them, as enough has been
 adduced in ansWer to the Jesuit; and something must
 be said of the destruction of the indexes and margins

 _ in the works of the Fathers.

 . It being thought advisable to deal gently with the
 early Ecclesiastical writers, lest the damnatory volumes
 should fall into the hands of enemies, theonly resource
 left for those who dreaded the test of Catholic antiquity,
 was to obliterate all references to hostile passages, and
 thus, revent every one but the very careful student,
 from Forming true ideas of the doctrines held in former
 times. Quamobrem quod in hos non audent, in nos-
 tros cudunt; δι marginum, annotationum, indicﬁmque
 _ dicta furcillis suis extrudunt, quamuis cum Patrﬂ mente

 V censonantia.3-—I shall select specimens from St. einatm-
